Commun. 1995; 213: 24-31Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar), as well as others.Recently, we demonstrated that red blood cell ä-spectrin is also a specific substrate for ubiquitination (28Corsi D. Galluzzi L. Crinelli R. Magnani M. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 8928-8935Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). ä- and β-spectrin are the major protein constituents of the red blood cell membrane skeleton and contribute to about 25% of total red cell membrane proteins. This membrane skeleton provides support for the overlying lipid bilayer and contributes to the viscoelastic properties and deformability of the membrane (29Cohen C.M. Semin. Hematol. 1983; 20: 141-158PubMed Google Scholar).The spectrin molecule is composed of two subunits with apparent molecular masses of 240 kDa (ä-spectrin) and 220 kDa (β-spectrin), intertwined side-to-side to form a heterodimer. The two ä and β subunits of spectrin are different not only in molecular mass but also in constitution. In fact, the ä-spectrin chain consists of series of 22 repeats of 106 residues, whereas the β chain consists of 17 repeats of 106 residues (30Bennet V. Physiol. Rev. 1990; 70: 1029-1065Crossref PubMed Scopus (356) Google Scholar). The tryptic digestion of spectrin gave evidence of a linear disposition of trypsin-resistant domains (31Speicher D.W. Morrow J.S. Knowles W.L. Marchesi V.T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1980; 77: 5673-5677Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). Five domains were defined on the ä chain (äI to äV from the N terminus) and four on β chain (βI to βIV from the C terminus). The heterodimer ä-β assembly requires a specific nucleation site located in the äV and βIV domains (32Speicher D.W. Weglarz L. DeSilva T.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 14775-14782Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). A self-association between the N-terminal region of the ä chain and the C-terminal region of the β chain is involved in the formation of a tetramer, which is the predominant form in the erythrocyte (33Ji T.H. Kiehm D.J. Middaugh C.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1980; 255: 2990-2993Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar).Moreover, spectrin forms noncovalent associations with other proteins of the cytoskeleton, such as band 2.1 (34Kennedy S. Warren S. Forget B. Morrow J. J. Cell Biol. 1991; 115: 267-277Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar), band 4.1, and actin (35Cohen C.M. Gascard P. Semin. Hematol. 1992; 29: 244-292PubMed Google Scholar). Other proteins such as adducin, tropomyosin, tropomodulin, and dematin function as accessory proteins of spectrin-actin junctions and are probably involved in the stabilization of spectrin-actin complexes (36Bennet V. Gilligan D.M. Annu. Rev. Cell Biol. 1993; 9: 27-66Crossref PubMed Scopus (444) Google Scholar). Furthermore, spectrin and protein 4.1 interact through phosphatidylserine with the inner leaflet of the lipid bilayer (37Rybicki A.C. Heath R. Lubin B. Schwartz R.S. J. Clin. Invest. 1988; 81: 255-260Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar).In an attempt to gain insight into the potential biological role of ä-spectrin ubiquitination, we searched for the site(s) of ubiquitination present on ä-spectrin. The data reported in this study show that ubiquitination occurs on the äIII and äV domains of ä-spectrin, suggesting that at least ubiquitination of the äV domain can play a role in cytoskeleton stability mediated by the ä-β-spectrin nucleation site.DISCUSSIONSpectrin is the principal component of the erythrocyte membrane skeleton and plays a dominant role in determining such mechanical properties of the erythrocyte as elasticity and deformability (47Mohandas N. Chasis J.A. Semin. Hematol. 1993; 30: 171-192PubMed Google Scholar). Membrane equilibrium depends on the structural integrity of the skeletal proteins and on normal molecular interactions between the cytoskeletal proteins and membrane. Moreover, the binding of cytosolic components such as enzymes and hemoglobin to cytoskeletal proteins can play a role in membrane stability. Among the factors that may serve as regulators of cytoskeletal organization is protein phosphorylation-dephosphorylation (36Bennet V. Gilligan D.M. Annu. Rev. Cell Biol. 1993; 9: 27-66Crossref PubMed Scopus (444) Google Scholar). β-Spectrin has been reported to be a substrate for cytosol and membranous casein kinases. In particular, this chain contains a cluster of six phosphorylation sites. Phosphorylation of spectrin has been shown not to affect either dimer-dimer associations (48Ungewickell E. Gratzer W. Eur. J. Biochem. 1978; 88: 379-385Crossref PubMed Scopus (222) Google Scholar) or spectrin binding to ankyrin in vitro (49Lu P.-W. Soong C.-J. Tao M. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 14958-14964Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). However, phosphorylation affects spectrin inextractability from “inside-out” vesicles (50Lutz H.V. Stringaro-Wipf G. Maretzki D. J. Cardiovasc. Pharmacol. 1986; 8: 576-579Google Scholar) and modulates the mechanical function and stability of the intact membrane structure (51Manno S. Takakuwa Y. Nagao K. Mohandas N. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 5659-5665Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (125) Google Scholar). Other mediators, such as Ca2+ and calmodulin, can also regulate membrane stability (52Takakuwa Y. Mohandas N. J. Clin. Invest. 1988; 82: 394-400Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar). Interestingly, free calmodulin can be ubiquitinated in a Ca2+-dependent manner and subsequently degraded, a process which could act as a control mechanism for all free calmodulin in excess (53Ziegenhagen R. Jennissen H.P. Biol. Chem. Hoppe-Seyler. 1988; 369: 1317-1324Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). Recently, we described and characterized a new posttranslational modification of erythrocyte ä-spectrin in which ubiquitin binds covalently to the ä-spectrin chain (28Corsi D. Galluzzi L. Crinelli R. Magnani M. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 8928-8935Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar).In this report, using different approaches, we demonstrate the existence of two binding sites for ubiquitin on ä-spectrin. Digestion with endoprotease Lys C of ubiquitinated spectrin revealed the presence of two 125I-Ub peptides of Mr 40,000 and 29,000. As shown by Western blotting, these radiolabeled peptides were recognized by polyclonal IgG anti-äV domain and anti-äIII domain, respectively, indicating that these two peptides are the sites of ubiquitination on red blood cell ä-spectrin. It could be speculated that ä-spectrin ubiquitination on domains III and V may play a role in membrane stability as found for other mediators of red blood cell membrane. The äIII domain is not associated to any known function, whereas the äV domain contains the nucleation site for association with the β chain (32Speicher D.W. Weglarz L. DeSilva T.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 14775-14782Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and is involved in Ca2+ binding (54Lundberg S. Lehto V.P. Backman L. Biochemistry. 1992; 31: 5665-5671Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar) and, with the βIV domain, participates in the interaction with actin and protein 4.1 (55Husain A. Howlett G.J. Sawyer W.H. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1984; 122: 1194-1200Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar). Interestingly, the äV domain is involved in the ubiquitination of ä-spectrin and contains repeats 20 through 22, which exhibit atypical features. In fact, there is insertion of several amino acids into the repeats 20 and 21. Moreover, repeat 22 has a reduced homology to a typical spectrin repeat. Moreover, the nucleation site present in the äV domain is not only responsible for the initial ä-β spectrin binding but also controls the side-to-side register of the many homologous repeats in both subunits. An unusual feature of the nucleation regions is that three of the repeats (two in the ä and one in the β subunits) have an eight-residue insertion in the normal 106-residue repeat unit (32Speicher D.W. Weglarz L. DeSilva T.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 14775-14782Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). These eight-residue insertions, which contain a lysine residue, might confer unique conformational properties upon the nucleation site, and the ubiquitination of domain äV might play a role in this context. The erythroblast-to-erythrocyte maturation process is accompanied by changes in the composition and properties of the plasma membrane. Furthermore, mature erythrocytes are incapable of ubiquitin/26 S proteosome-dependent degradation (56Speiser S. Etlinger J.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 14122-14127Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Thus, ubiquitination of ä-spectrin could play two different roles during erythrocyte maturation. In erythroblasts, the amount of ä-spectrin synthesized exceeds by more than 3-fold the amount assembled on the membrane, and the excess unassembled peptides are rapidly degraded (57Lazarides E. Moon R.J. Cell. 1984; 37: 354Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar). It could be speculated that the binding of ubiquitin to ä-spectrin in erythroblasts involves subsequent degradation. It is important to note that the sequence of ä-spectrin contains a glutamic residue in the first position that may act as a secondary destabilizing residue according to the N-end rule (58Varshavsky A. Cell. 1992; 69: 725-735Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (389) Google Scholar) when spectrin is in the unassembled form. The second determinant, a specific internal lysine residue, could be the first lysine located at position 5 or 15 (domain I) of the ä-spectrin sequence. Excess hemoglobin subunits are subject to an analogous targeted degradation in thalassemia (59Shaeffer J.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 13172-13177Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Because, as shown in this report, ubiquitination occurs in mature red blood cells on the äIII and äV domains, and thus quite far from the äI domain (moreover, these cells are incapable of ubiquitin/26 S proteosome-dependent degradation), the ubiquitination process of assembled ä-spectrin probably has a different role in these cells than in erythroblasts. Ubiquitin itself and/or multiubiquitin chains could have a potential function as conformation-perturbing devices when conjugated to cytoskeletal proteins, given their orientational flexibility and reversibility (60Varshavsky A. Bachmair A. Finley D. Gonda D. Wünning I. Rechsteiner M. Ubiquitin. Plenum Press, New York1988: 287-324Crossref Google Scholar). Thus, we suggest that the ubiquitination of ä-spectrin in mature erythrocytes should be considered a new posttranslational event with a regulatory role in spectrin function rather than a signal for ä-spectrin degradation. In fact, ubiquitination is a dynamic process (28Corsi D. Galluzzi L. Crinelli R. Magnani M. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 8928-8935Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar), the linkage is covalent, and a significant amount (3% of the total ä-spectrin chain) is continuously ubiquitinated in erythrocytes. As reported previously for globin-spectrin complex formation during erythrocyte senescence (61Fortier N. Snyder L.M. Garver F. Kiefer C. McKenney J. Mohandas N. Blood. 1988; 71: 1427-1431Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), such an amount could account for a significant change in membrane deformability. We also investigated whether other proteins belonging to the spectrin superfamily are ubiquitinated. Brain ä-fodrin was not found to be a substrate for ubiquitin in an in vitro assay. This non-erythroid spectrin and erythroid ä-spectrin have very similar sequences (54% identity) throughout their entire length (62Sahr K.E. Laurila P. Kotula L. Scarpa A.L. Coupal E. Leto T.L. Linnenbach A.J. Winkelmann J.C. Speicher D.W. Marchesi V.T. Curtis P.J. Forget B.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 4434-4443Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), but interestingly, fodrin at its C-terminal has an atypical sequence of 150 residues in repeat 22 (äV domain), and the identity of the 37 residues at the very C-terminal is less than 10%. Moreover, fodrin differs considerably from erythrocyte ä-spectrin in repeats 11 and 12 (äIII domain) and possesses a calmodulin-binding site in the latter repeat that is absent in ä-spectrin (63Winkelmann J.C. Forget B.G. Blood. 1993; 81: 3173-3185Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Thus, erythrocyte ä-spectrin and brain fodrin differ mainly in the domains found to be susceptible to ubiquitination. It would be interesting to examine whether ä-actinin, another protein of the spectrin superfamily, is ubiquitinated. In particular, repeats 20 through 22, together with the nonrepeat C terminus of ä-spectrin, are highly homologous with the C terminus of ä-actinin (64Baron M.D. Davison M.D. Jones P. Critchley D.R. Biochem. Soc. Trans. 1987; 15: 796Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). Preliminary studies now in progress in our laboratory indicate that ä-actinin is ubiquitinated, at least in vivo. To date, no information is available on the function of the äIII domain of ä-spectrin, but because the carboxyl terminus of the ä-spectrin subunits (äV domain) is involved in the binding of the β-spectrin chain to form the ä-β dimer and is an important site for many mediators in red blood cells, the ubiquitination of this cytoskeletal protein may be of physiological significance. INTRODUCTIONUbiquitin (Ub), 1The abbreviations used are: UbubiquitinE1Ub activating enzymeE2Ub carrier proteinE3Ub-protein isopeptide ligasemeUbmethylated UbPAGEpolyacrylamide gel electrophoresisAEBSF4-(2-aminoethyl)-benzenesulfonyl fluoride hydrochloridePMSFphenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride. a 76-amino acid protein, has been found both free and covalently bound to target proteins via an isopeptide linkage between the carboxyl group of the terminal glycine moiety of Ub and free ϵ amino groups on the target protein (1Haas A.L. Bright P.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 12464-12473Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Rabbit reticulocyte fraction II (2Hershko A. Heller H. Elias S. Ciechanover A. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 8206-8214Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) (protein adsorbed to DEAE 52-cellulose and eluted with 0.5 M KCl) contains the enzymatic system (E1, E2 s, E3 s) that is involved in ubiquitin conjugation. Usually, a protein can have one or more sites for ubiquitin, in which one ubiquitin or multiubiquitin chains can be linked. In the latter case, one Ub is linked to the lysine 48 of another ubiquitin bound to the substrate (3Chau V. Tobias J.V. Bachmair A. Ecker C.K. Science. 1989; 243: 1576-1583Crossref PubMed Scopus (1103) Google Scholar). Ub-conjugated proteins can either be degraded to small peptides by a large 26 S ATP-dependent protease complex, or the Ub moiety can be removed by Ub isopeptidases, releasing ubiquitin and the intact protein (4Hersko A. Ciechanover A. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1992; 61: 761-807Crossref PubMed Scopus (1191) Google Scholar). Protein ubiquitination is a posttranslational process involved not only in protein degradation but also in other cellular functions. In fact, many studies have reported the in vivo presence of several stable Ub-protein conjugates that are not subject to degradation (5Finley D. Chau U. Annu. Rev. Cell Biol. 1991; 7: 25-69Crossref PubMed Scopus (421) Google Scholar, 6Mayer R.J. Arnold J. Làszlò L. Landon M. Lowe J. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1991; 1089: 141-157Crossref PubMed Scopus (115) Google Scholar). Moreover, another linkage in which ubiquitin is linked to a previously bound Ub involves lysine 63 of Ub, and these chains serve nonproteolytic functions (7Arnason T. Ellison M.J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1994; 14: 7876-7883Crossref PubMed Scopus (195) Google Scholar). In general, ubiquitin is involved in different cellular processes such as transcriptional regulation (8Levinger L. Varshavsky A. Cell. 1982; 28: 375-385Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (236) Google Scholar), cell cycle regulation (9Glotzer M. Murray A.W. Kirschner M.W. Nature. 1991; 349: 132-138Crossref PubMed Scopus (1886) Google Scholar), stress responses (10Bond U. Agell N. Haas A.L. Redman K. Schlesinger M.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 2384-2388Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), and modulation of the immune response (11St. John T. Gallantin W.N.M. Siegelman M. Smith H.T. Fried V.A. Weissmann I.L. Science. 1988; 231: 845-850Crossref Scopus (110) Google Scholar). In particular, in the last decade Ub has been found to be bound to many specific substrates such as lysozyme (12Hough R. Pratt G. Rechsteiner M. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 2400-2408Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), phytochrome (13Shanklin J. Jabben M. Viestra R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 359-363Crossref PubMed Scopus (169) Google Scholar), actin (14Ball E. Karlik C.C. Beall C.J. Saville D. Sparrow J.C. Bullard B. Fyberg E.A. Chem. 1990; 265: 21664-21669Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), calmodulin (16Ziegenhagen R. Goldberg M. Rakutt W.D. Jennissen H.P. FEBS Lett. 1990; 271: 71-75Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar), cAMP-dependent protein kinase (17Hedge A.N. Goldberg A.L. Schwartz J.H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. 1993; 90: 7436-7440Crossref PubMed Scopus (185) Google Scholar), p53 (18Scheffner M. Huibregste J.M. Viestra R.D. Howley P.M. Cell. 1993; 75: 495-505Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1952) Google Scholar), ABC-transporter Ste 6 protein (19Kolling R. Hollenberg C.P. EMBO J. 1994; 13: 3261-3271Crossref PubMed Scopus (271) Google Scholar), c-jun (20Treier M. Staszewski L.M. Bohmann D. Cell. 1994; 78: 773-785Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1914) Google Scholar), inhibitor of κB-ä (24Henkel T. Machleidt T. Alkalay I. KrÖnke M. Ben-Neriah Y. Baeuerle P.A. Nature. 1993; 365: 182-185Crossref PubMed Scopus (1034) Google Scholar), platelet-derived growth factor-β, and ä receptors, and epidermal growth factor, colony-stimulating factor-I, fibroblast growth factor (25Mori S. Claesson-Welsh L. Okuyama Y. Saito Y. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1995; 213: 32-39Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar), cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (26Ward C.L. Commun. 1995; 213: 24-31Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar), as well as others.Recently, we demonstrated that red blood cell ä-spectrin is also a specific substrate for ubiquitination (28Corsi D. Galluzzi L. Crinelli R. Magnani M. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 8928-8935Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). ä- and β-spectrin are the major protein constituents of the red blood cell membrane skeleton and contribute to about 25% of total red cell membrane proteins. This membrane skeleton provides support for the overlying lipid bilayer and contributes to the viscoelastic properties and deformability of the membrane (29Cohen C.M. Semin. Hematol. 1983; 20: 141-158PubMed Google Scholar).The spectrin molecule is composed of two subunits with apparent molecular masses of 240 kDa (ä-spectrin) and 220 kDa (β-spectrin), intertwined side-to-side to form a heterodimer. The two ä and β subunits of spectrin are different not only in molecular mass but also in constitution. In fact, the ä-spectrin chain consists of series of 22 repeats of 106 residues, whereas the β chain consists of 17 repeats of 106 residues (30Bennet V. Physiol. Rev. 1990; 70: 1029-1065Crossref PubMed Scopus (356) Google Scholar). The tryptic digestion of spectrin gave evidence of a linear disposition of trypsin-resistant domains (31Speicher D.W. Morrow J.S. Knowles W.L. Marchesi V.T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1980; 77: 5673-5677Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). Five domains were defined on the ä chain (äI to äV from the N terminus) and four on β chain (βI to βIV from the C terminus). The heterodimer ä-β assembly requires a specific nucleation site located in the äV and βIV domains (32Speicher D.W. Weglarz L. DeSilva T.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 14775-14782Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). A self-association between the N-terminal region of the ä chain and the C-terminal region of the β chain is involved in the formation of a tetramer, which is the predominant form in the erythrocyte (33Ji T.H. Kiehm D.J. Middaugh C.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1980; 255: 2990-2993Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar).Moreover, spectrin forms noncovalent associations with other proteins of the cytoskeleton, such as band 2.1 (34Kennedy S. Warren S. Forget B. Morrow J. J. Cell Biol. 1991; 115: 267-277Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar), band 4.1, and actin (35Cohen C.M. Gascard P. Semin. Hematol. 1992; 29: 244-292PubMed Google Scholar). Other proteins such as adducin, tropomyosin, tropomodulin, and dematin function as accessory proteins of spectrin-actin junctions and are probably involved in the stabilization of spectrin-actin complexes (36Bennet V. Gilligan D.M. Annu. Rev. Cell Biol. 1993; 9: 27-66Crossref PubMed Scopus (444) Google Scholar). Furthermore, spectrin and protein 4.1 interact through phosphatidylserine with the inner leaflet of the lipid bilayer (37Rybicki A.C. Heath R. Lubin B. Schwartz R.S. J. Clin. Invest. 1988; 81: 255-260Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar).In an attempt to gain insight into the potential biological role of ä-spectrin ubiquitination, we searched for the site(s) of ubiquitination present on ä-spectrin. The data reported in this study show that ubiquitination occurs on the äIII and äV domains of ä-spectrin, suggesting that at least ubiquitination of the äV domain can play a role in cytoskeleton stability mediated by the ä-β-spectrin nucleation site.
